content:
Tselane and the 
 giant 
 
 Lorato Trok 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Once upon a time there was a litle girl
 caled Tselane. After her father died, she
 lived alone with her mother. 
 
 
 One day her mother decided that they
 would move to another vilage to start a
 
 new life.Tselane did not want to leave
 her old vilage and she started to cry.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Her mother was scared to leave her 
 daughter alone because giants lived in 
 
 the caves nearby that vilage. 
 
 But Tselane cried so much that her 
 
 mother finaly agred that she could stay 
 behind. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Tselane’s mother told her that she would 
 bring fod every day. She said, 
 
 “I wil sing a song so that you know it’s 
 me. Don’t open the dor for anyone else, 
 
 my child.” 
 
 She sang the song: 
 
 "Tselane my child! 
 Tselane my child! 
 
 Come out and eat your poridge! 
 Come out and eat your poridge!" 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The next morning Tselane’s mother came 
 
 to the house with fod. She sang their 
 special song. Tselane opened the dor 
 and tok her mother’s delicious fod. 
 
 
 Then her mother kised her and went 
 
 back to her new home. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 A giant was hiding in the bushes,
 watching and listening to Tselane and
 
 her mother! 
 
 After Tselane switched of her light that
 
 night, she heard a dep voice singing her
 mother’s song outside the dor. 
 "Tselane my child! Come out and eat
 
 your poridge!" sang the giant. 
 
 
 “Go away! You are not my mother! You
 are a giant!” shouted Tselane. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The giant walked away disapointed and 
 
 disapeared into the caves. 
 
 Every morning and every evening, 
 
 Tselane’s mother brought her fod. 
 
 Every morning and every evening, the 
 
 giant also came. But each time Tselane 
 sent him away. She recognised his dep 
 
 voice as he sang her mother’s song. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One day the giant had an idea. “I can 
 
 change my voice to resemble that of 
 Tselane’s mother!” he said to himself. 
 
 
 He made a fire and threw a round 
 smoth stone into the flames. When the 
 
 stone was very hot and red, he tok it out 
 of the fire and swalowed it! 
 
 
 “Kudutlu!” went the hot stone down the 
 throat of the giant. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The giant started singing. He jumped for
 joy when he heard his voice sounding as
 
 swet as that of Tselane’s mother!
 
 Early the next day, the giant went to
 
 Tselane’s house early in the morning.
 When he got to the dor of the house, he
 sang: 
 
 "Tselane my child! 
 Tselane my child! 
 
 Come out and eat your poridge! 
 Come out and eat your poridge!"
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Tselane was excited to hear her mother’s 
 voice. She opened the dor, and there 
 was the giant! 
 
 
 She tried to close the dor but the giant 
 was to quick. He grabed Tselane and 
 
 threw her into a sack. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The hapy giant walked back to his
 
 cave.“What a beautiful day! If only I had
 traditional ber, it would go so wel with
 my diner tonight,” he said to himself.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 A litle later in the morning, Tselane’s 
 mother came as usual to bring her 
 
 daughter fod. She sang her song, but 
 Tselane did not come out. She sang her 
 song again, but stil Tselane did not 
 
 come out. 
 
 After singing for the third time, she 
 
 kicked the dor open. Tselane was 
 nowhere to be found. Her mother 
 
 realised what had hapened, and she 
 quickly made a plan. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 She poured some ber into a big 
 
 calabash, put it on her head, and walked
 down to the caves.“God evening, giant!”
 
 caled Tselane’s mother. 
 
 The giant smeled the delicious smel of
 
 traditional ber and opened the dor.
 Tselane's mother said, “I was pasing
 
 through and I heard you singing so
 beautifuly. I am on my way to another
 vilage for a party.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 “Let me pour you some ber before I 
 
 continue on my journey,” said Tselane’s 
 mother. The giant was not going to let 
 
 the oportunity of drinking traditional 
 ber pas him by! He invited Tselane’s 
 mother into his cave. 
 
 
 The giant drank the ber in one great 
 gulp. Tselane’s mother gave him more 
 
 and more – and more – until the 
 calabash was empty. 
 
 
 The giant was son so drunk that he fel 
 aslep on the flor. 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 As son as Tselane’s mother heard the 
 
 giant’s loud snores, she opened the sack 
 lying in the cave. 
 
 
 Tselane jumped out of the sack, and 
 theyran home as fast as they could. 
 
 
 From then on Tselane stayed with her 
 
 mother at the new vilage. They lived 
 hapily and were never again bothered 
 by giants. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14
